scenes.background: You are leading a project team that has just received an urgent assignment requiring a significant amount of work to be completed within a tight deadline. The team is feeling a lot of pressure, and morale is low, with some members showing signs of frustration and anxiety. One of the team members, Alex, says, 'This is impossible! We can't get this done in time.' You responded by suggesting breaking the tasks into smaller parts. The team seemed somewhat relieved but still on edge. [Monica] and [Bob] exchange concerned looks. Monica then speaks up, 'Even with smaller tasks, the deadline is still too tight.' Bob, looking frustrated, adds, 'I don't think anyone here believes we can actually pull this off.' You then acknowledged the team's feelings and opened the floor for discussion. Monica sighed and mentioned that discussing concerns won't expand the deadline. Bob muttered that the situation felt like a disaster waiting to happen. You then encouraged the team to stay focused and do their best. Now, Monica, looking exasperated, says, 'Staying focused is one thing, but we still have a mountain of work and no extra hands.'
scenes.description: Bob, crossing his arms, says, 'Maybe we should just accept that we're going to fail. Lower our expectations.'

options.text: I hear your concerns, Monica. Let's see if we can bring in some extra help or reallocate resources to lighten the load.
options.analysis: You acknowledged the team's concerns and proposed a practical solution, demonstrating empathy and good social skills.

options.text: I know it's a lot, but we need to keep going. If we stay focused and organized, we can make progress.
options.analysis: You encouraged the team to stay focused and work together, showing good self-regulation and motivational skills.

options.text: If anyone has a more efficient way to tackle this, please share it. Otherwise, we should just get on with the work.
options.analysis: You opened the floor for suggestions but also pushed the team to continue working, showing moderate emotion perception and self-regulation.
